title: How is knowledge exchanged and shared when interdisciplinary research teams work together? - Quora

response.answer_text: The researchers identified patterns by conducting intensive fieldwork on three interdisciplinary collaborative projects at a German university. The studies included different methods to investigate both the cognitions and the interactions of the members of the interdisciplinary teams. "Using the cognitive mapping method, the participants were able to show how the ideas and knowledge of the team members were being shared in collaborative exchange and integrated into a common knowledge structure." "The first, which they refer to as the "theory-method interdisciplinary collaboration pattern," involves one party providing a theoretical understanding, and the other offering methods for collecting and analysing the data. The second, which was called the "technical interdisciplinary collaborative pattern," is characterised by the exchange of learning tools such as algorithms and technical know-how to solve a shared research question." For instance, they found that interdisciplinary teams can save time and money if they agree on goals, communication rules and research tools in a kick-off meeting. They also need to discuss the understanding of their basic concepts -- which is usually different! Further on in the course of the project, it is helpful to explicitly agree on the way in which research results are to be integrated."

The last point is that “ Knowledge is a fluid and contagious commodity” for those who are in the vicinity of the people involved in the exchange and sharing of ideas for “ bringing something new” for the betterment of human society!!

There is scholarly research on this question. The person best known for this work, and who does excellent research, is Carole L. Palmer. Her book, Work at the Boundaries of Science: iInformation and the Interdisciplinary Research Process, describes an extensive research project she did observing scientists working across several disciplines on their research for a major project. Of course, the technology has changed since the 2001 publication date, but what is important about her study is what she finds out about how the scientists think about and compensate for the difficulties of working across disciplinary boundaries. She is now a professor in the University of Washington Information School. Here is a more recent review she and colleagues did on the research that is available on scholarly research practices. https://www.oclc.org/content/dam/research/publications/library/2009/2009-02.pdf

“A study makes concrete recommendations for how teams can best work together and achieve effective collaborations. The results have been published in the journal Nature. The study observed two fundamental patterns of knowledge exchange and integration in interdisciplinary research teams," says Boos. "The first, which we refer to as the "theory-method interdisciplinary collaboration pattern," involves one party providing a theoretical understanding, and the other offering methods for collecting and analysing the data. The second, which we called the "technical interdisciplinary collaborative pattern," is characterised by the exchange of learning tools such as algorithms and technical know-how to solve a shared research question." Knowledge-sharing: a how-to guide

I am a strong believer that the opportunity for breakthroughs is optimized at the intersection of disciplines. Why is that? Successful researchers are naturally curious and creating an environment where social interactions occur easily allows individuals to venture into topics that they might otherwise miss. For example, the Computer Science building at Stanford was designed to provide community spaces for researchers to meet informally. Another building, the Center for Integrated Systems was designed to house researchers in both Computer Science and Electrical Engineering. This was expanded later to include space for researchers in many disciplines to share the expensive equipment in that facility under an NSF program. The result was an explosion of new ideas. Good researchers cannot resist talking with each other about their research and that eureka moment occurs when a new insight is realized.

It’s not like a pre-conference cocktail where researchers with a drink in hand have a loose chat with other participants. For interdisciplinary research to happen you need capable team leaders who will organize their team members and assign tasks. There is appropriate communication software on both sides and it is used to exchange and share knowledge in a regular fashion. When your interdisciplinary research project gets finalized the teams might organize a joint event to release the outcomes and if the results are of interest to general public, members of the public will be invited as well as journalists.

I think the crucial key to “interdisciplinary” work is that the participants need to be willing and able to set aside their personal agendas for the greater goal. This works best when the participants have tremendous mutual respect for each other and are willing to step well beyond the traditional bounds of their respective fields. They have to be willing to be a bit vulnerable, share data, ideas, codes, techniques, and CREDIT. You have to be willing to be challenged and pushed and return this to the group in a fair and respectful way. I like to say that “There is no “I” in this TEAM…and if you think there is, then there is no “U” in it either.”

If there are N disciplines in the group, then you personally have only 1/Nth of the knowledge needed to get the job done. A psychology colleague told me that about 1/2 of the time allotted to the project is spent pooling the knowledge needed. I’ve been on lots of really well oiled groups and on some real Hells. You need to have a group that works socially (there’s lots of stuff about group roles) together and those people have to have a real desire to hear out other members.

How does one eat an elephant? One bite at a time. Interdisciplinary teams break tasks into component parts and structure pathways to make connections where each discipline connects to others. There are truly no isolated disciplines, only disciplines that focus on a primary task that they consider relevant to the outcomes they seek. A team builds a matrix that has no bias toward any single discipline and set aside any attendant egos…

Interdisciplinary research is an excellent opportunity to expand the boundaries of human knowledge. I am not sure what you mean by “how” — do you mean the logistics of exchanging and sharing information? If so, all the communication methods known to humankind can be used: Face-to-Face, email, shared documents, (I hesitate to include social media, but possibly even that), …

The Blue Brain Nexus project is one state-of-the-art example of how interdisciplinary research team knowledge is shared at scale using W3C standards-based knowledge graph approaches.  Blue Brain Nexus
